awd_titl_txt: Genomic Structure of Founder Events in the 17th Century Chesapeake
awd_abstract_narration:
This award was provided as part of NSF's Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships (SPRF) program. The goal of the SPRF program is to prepare promising, early career doctoral-level scientists for scientific careers in academia, industry or private sector, and government. SPRF awards involve two years of training under the sponsorship of established scientists and encourage Postdoctoral Fellows to perform independent research. NSF seeks to promote the participation of scientists from all segments of the scientific community, including those from underrepresented groups, in its research programs and activities; the postdoctoral period is considered to be an important level of professional development in attaining this goal. Each Postdoctoral Fellow must address important scientific questions that advance their respective disciplinary fields. Under the sponsorship of Dr. Deborah Bolnick at the University of Connecticut, this postdoctoral fellowship award supports an early career scientist assessing how founder effects shaped patterns of genomic variation during the 17th century colonization of the Chesapeake colonies (Maryland, Virginia, and Delaware). This project seeks to (1) characterize the genomes of archaeological individuals recovered from the Jamestown archaeological site, compare their genomic variation with (2) additional 17th century Chesapeake archaeological burials, and (3) with contemporary descendant populations in the other regions to assess if and when initial founder events contributed to contemporary genomic variation in the region. This research utilizes a community engaged framework, in which successive outreach programs and workshops held in collaboration with the Jamestown Rediscovery Project share progress and the results of the research with community stakeholders.

When new populations are founded, the founders carry a random subset of the total genetic variation present in the ancestral source population, which can greatly influence genomic variation in descendant populations. This is especially relevant for understanding which of the multiple waves of migration have contributed most to contemporary population diversity. Genomic comparisons between contemporary and archaeological populations allows us to revisit this issue from a new perspective. In this project, we will sequence the genomes of archaeological individuals belonging to the first (A.D. 1607) settlers in Jamestown, Virginia. Their genomes will be compared with additional archaeological genomes from three sites in 17th century Chesapeake region as well as contemporary populations from other regions. Through this approach, we will directly assess population structure across archaeological sites, and determine the degree of similarity with contemporary populations. Due to rapid population turnover characteristic of 17th century Chesapeake settler populations, we expect that later population movements in the 17th century Chesapeake contributed more to contemporary population diversity than did earlier settlements. By analyzing the genomes of a time series of archaeological samples throughout the 17th century, beginning with the first settlers in Jamestown, Virginia, we can reconstruct the genomic population structure through 17th century Chesapeake to determine how and when founder events in colonization contexts began to contribute to present-day population diversity in the region.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This project sought to assess how founder effects shaped genomic diversity patterns during the first 100 years of European settlement in the 17th-century Chesapeake (Maryland, Virginia, and Delaware). Utilizing a time series of human remains excavated from historic archaeological sites, starting with the 1607 AD Jamestown settlement, we investigated how founder events in colonization contexts influenced present-day population diversity in the region. This information is crucial for understanding which waves of migration from Europe to North America during the Early Modern era significantly contributed to contemporary population diversity. Additionally, this research addressed historical questions about the early colonization of eastern North America. The extraction and sequencing of DNA from the original 1607 AD Jamestown settlers provided essential insights into the ancestry, genetic sex, and biological relationships among the first colonists. The novel genetic information generated in this study offered an alternative approach to the historical and archaeological study of Jamestown, providing deeper insights into the history of the first permanent English settlement in North America.

 

To achieve these goals, we collected DNA samples from 15 archaeological individuals from the AD 1607 Burial Ground in Jamestown, Virginia. The samples were analyzed at the University of Connecticut’s ancient DNA laboratory, and DNA was successfully extracted and sequenced for 13 of the 15 individuals. We evaluated whether post-mortem damage or exogenous contamination were present to assess the likelihood that the collected DNA sequences were authentic ancient DNA. The sequences from six individuals (46%) met our stringent authentication criteria. This success rate is not surprising given the long-term handling of osteological remains without proper personal protective equipment. Notably, DNA from individuals recently excavated with proper protective equipment exhibited much higher levels of authenticity, highlighting the importance of using such equipment and extracting ancient DNA promptly after excavation for higher success rates.

 

The ancient DNA sequences from these six Jamestown individuals were analyzed to infer their ancestry, biological relatedness, and genetic sex. Sex estimation aligned with osteological evidence, identifying five males and one female. Ancestry analysis compared genomic sequences from these individuals to global reference populations, and indicated strong similarity with contemporary European populations, particularly from western and northwestern Europe. Mitochondrial and Y-chromosome lineages consistently supported European origin, reinforcing historical records documenting the English roots of the Jamestown Company. Identity-by-descent analysis revealed no close genetic relatedness among the six individuals, confirming the hypothesis that these individuals were unrelated. These results represent the earliest ancient DNA  collected to date from colonial European populations in North America.

 

These data were then compared with ancient DNA data from 29 individuals from three Chesapeake archaeological sites—Patuxent Point (~1650-1680, Maryland), Calverton (~1660-1680s, Maryland), and Avery’s Rest (~1680-1710, Delaware)—forming a 17th-century time series. The Jamestown ancient DNA data were also compared to contemporary populations in the United Kingdom and the Chesapeake region, including 125 living putative descendants of 17th-century Chesapeake colonists. Through this analysis, we directly assessed population structure (PCA, ADMIXTURE) among archaeological sites and the degree of similarity with contemporary populations (PCA, F-statistics). Due to the rapid population turnover characteristic of 17th-century Chesapeake settler populations, we anticipate that later individuals will share more genetic variants with contemporary populations, suggesting a greater contribution to contemporary population diversity than the earlier settlements studied here.

 

Throughout this research, we contributed to public science education by developing web application tools in collaboration with the Jamestown Rediscovery Foundation. Our contributions to the Jamestown Rediscovery website include video, photographic content, and written material describing the project's goals, ethical ethos, and the process of conducting ancient DNA research. Additionally, we created a 3D model of the University of Connecticut’s ancient DNA lab, featuring video and photography demonstrating lab analyses conducted in the project, all aimed at enhancing the transparency of ancient DNA research through accessible educational content.


Last Modified: 01/15/2024
Modified by: Raquel E Fleskes
